title.narrative: Just Future - South Sudan

description.narrative: Just Future will work in solidarity with CSOs in each country—especially those representing women, young people, displaced people, and identity-based groups—enabling them to represent the voices of the most excluded at the local, national, regional, and global levels. The project will work with CSOs, CBOs, social movements, informal activist groups and community members (women and youth) as the primary stakeholders

Just Future’s vision is of a world in which all people in fragile states benefit from more accessible, responsive and accountable security and justice institutions, and more inclusive arrangements for political governance and peace-making.

The Just Future (JF) programme is a 5 years programme funded under the ‘Power of Voices’ framework by the Dutch Ministry of Foreign Affairs. Cordaid leads the Just Future Alliance that joins 6 coalition partners, 3 research institutions, around 25 local CSOs and an international civil society network. Through this partnership we work to strengthen capacity of civil society organizations in their role of lobby and advocacy. This will build on the previous phase of the strategic partnership from the MOFA called : “Dialogue and Dissent”- 2016-2020.
Fragility, conflict and violence are the most significant obstacles to achieving the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). Just 20% of fragile and conflict-affected states are on track to achieve SDG targets by 2030, when 85% of the world’s poorest people will be concentrated in those states; millions of people living in fragile contexts are at risk of being left behind. As it addresses fragility directly, SDG16 on peaceful, just, and inclusive societies is a vital accelerator of Agenda 2030. In the most fragile and conflict-affected contexts, insecurity and injustice is chronic and widespread due to weak, unresponsive institutions that do not meet the needs and claims of security and justice seekers, with adverse impact on the dignity, prosperity, and survival of all in society. The prevalence of insecurity and injustice also undermines people’s perception of the efficacy and legitimacy of the state, inducing the weak social contract at the heart of fragility. In 6 countries—Afghanistan, Burundi, Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC), Mali, Niger and South Sudan—fragility also manifests as lack of freedom and space for independent civic action. All 6 countries are amongst the world’s least free and most closed, due to repressive legislation and regulation by states, conservative or patriarchal social norms and informal institutions that restrict space for women and youth, the actions of violent non-state actors, or a combination thereof. In the cases of Afghanistan, Mali, and South Sudan, deficient processes of peacemaking or peace implementation are also present; 5 countries (all but Burundi) host large international peace and security assistance missions. Civil society organizations (CSOs), community-based organizations (CBOs), social movements, and informal activist groups in all 6 countries are working to improve security and justice and make political decision-making and peace processes more inclusive. CSOs, CBOs, social movements, and informal activist groups can aggregate and articulate the needs and demands of the most excluded constituencies, and engage on their behalf with duty-bearers and power-holders. But the relative weakness, fragmentation, and contested legitimacy of civil society in a context of shrinking civic space undermines the capacity of these actors to advocate for effective institutions or negotiate and collaborate with the state. Consequently, the demands and expectations of the most excluded are seldom reflected in the policy and practices of security, justice, governance and peace actors at the sub-national and national levels.

mailing-address.narrative: Grote Marktstraat 45, Den Haag, Zuid Holland, 2511 BH

title.narrative: Ownership and Inclusion
Percentage of women & youth representation in international and national steering committees

description.narrative: Increase of w/y membership in boards, leadership positions

title.narrative: Number of consultation sessions of programme partners with constituencies that inform strategic decision making and programming

description.narrative: Counts the number of consultation sessions.

comment.narrative: During the two inception workshops conducted in Wau and Yambio, the constituencies highted their priorities that is useful to inform EVE's strategic interventions.

title.narrative: People-centered Security
Number of dialogues with state actors to identify security problems that need to be addressed concerning SGBV

description.narrative: Counts the number of times that JF partners address SGBV concerns with state actors. SGBV is a crucial cross-sectional issue in the 3 Outcome areas and reducing SGBV requires addressing the functioning of security actors, the legal system and tensions, social norms and behavior underlying local conflicts.

comment.narrative: The National Women Leaders' Conference facilitated a dialogue about securiy issues women are facing both at the State and National level.
The National Women Leaders' Conference facilitated a dialogue about securiy issues women are facing both at the State and National level.

title.narrative: Number of Laws influenced by primary stakeholders (CSOs) that lead to more effective, accountable, inclusive, transparent and responsive security institutions

description.narrative: A robust legal framework, which is translated in inclusive policies, is essential to regulate well-functioning Security and Justice Institutions, and Peace Processes (3 Outcome Areas). Through L&A the JFA aims to influence policy reform. With this indicator, we aim to measure the number of laws and policies influenced result in changes benefitting our constituencies.

comment.narrative: In 2021 South Sudan Law Society with support from Cordaid under the Just Future Project formed and trained 42 members social movements including women, youth and IDPs in Kapoeta and Torit Eastern Equatoria State, South Sudan on lobby and advocacy and Democratic security Security Sector Governance to infleunce proper implementation of the security laws (National Security Service Act, South Sudan People's Liberation Army Act and the National Police Service Act) and ensure more effective, accountable, inclusive, transparent and responsive security institutions. The proper implementation of the said security laws will greatly contribute to improved security and prevent sexual and gender based violence, armed robberies and armed violence committed by persons in Uniform agaisnt women, youth and IDPs in Eastern Equatoria State.

title.narrative: Number of Policies influenced by primary stakeholders (CSOs) that lead to more effective, accountable, inclusive, transparent and responsive security institutions

description.narrative: A robust legal framework, which is translated in inclusive policies, is essential to regulate well-functioning Security and Justice Institutions, and Peace Processes (3 Outcome Areas). Through L&A the JFA aims to influence policy reform. With this indicator, we aim to measure the number of laws and policies influenced result in changes benefitting our constituencies.

comment.narrative: In November 2021, South Sudan Law Society with support from Cordaid under the Just Future Project held a training for civil society member and key security stakeholders including representatives of the Strategic Defense and Security Review Board, the Ministry of Defense and the Ministry of Interior on chapter II of the Revitalized Agreement on Resolution of the Conflict in South Sudan, 2018 (R-ARCSS)on Security Sector Reform. The training equiped the participants with knowledge on democratic security sector governance, reforms and chapter ii of the R-ARCSS. It also provided opportunity for the members of the civil society organisation to strategize with the key security actors for influencning effective implementation of chapter ii of the R-ARCSS which will lead to more effective, accountable, inclusive, transparent and responsive security institutions.

title.narrative: Access to Justice
Number of Laws influenced by primary stakeholders (CSOs) that lead to more effective, accountable, inclusive, transparent and responsive justice institutions

description.narrative: A robust legal framework, which is translated in inclusive policies, is essential to regulate well-functioning Security and Justice Institutions, and Peace Processes (3 Outcome Areas). Through L&A the JFA aims to influence policy reform. With this indicator, we aim to measure the number of laws and policies influenced result in changes benefitting our constituencies.

comment.narrative: In October and November 2021, South Sudan Law Society with support from Cordaid under the Just Future Project trained 100 Paralegals in Yei, Torit and Kapoeta, South Sudan support effective implementation of the laws and advocate for reform of laws ( Penal Code Act. Land Act, Criminal and Civil Procedures Acts). The Paralegals will continuously and sustainably provide legal information and advice to vulnerable persons including women, youth and IDPs while documenting unlawful justice practices and advocating for reform and proper implementation of these laws to ensure more effective, accountable, inclusive, transparent and responsive justice institutions.

title.narrative: Number of Policies influenced by primary stakeholders (CSOs) that lead to more effective, accountable, inclusive, transparent and responsive justice institutions

description.narrative: A robust legal framework, which is translated in inclusive policies, is essential to regulate well-functioning Security and Justice Institutions, and Peace Processes (3 Outcome Areas). Through L&A the JFA aims to influence policy reform. With this indicator, we aim to measure the number of laws and policies influenced result in changes benefitting our constituencies.

comment.narrative: On 7th and 8th December 2021, South Sudan Law Society with support from Cordaid under the Just Future Project held a held a two days dialogue on chapter V of the R-ARCSS on transitional Justice and inclusive and victims' centred transitional Justice with civil society and key governmment stakeholders including representatives of the Ministry of Justice and Constitutional Affairs, R-JMEC, South Sudan Human Rights Commission and members of technical committee for the Establishment of the Comission for Truth, Reconciliation and Healing (CTRH). The two days dialogue provided opportunity for the members of the civil society to discuss the challenges and opportunities for effective implementation of chapter V of the R-ARCSS and also to strategize with the key Transitional Justice stakeholders to influence effective implementation of chapter V of the R-ARCSS which will lead to more effective, accountable, inclusive, transparent and responsive Transitional Justice Institutions. This will ensure implementation of transitional justice process that prioritise and ensure meangingful inclusion, participation and access to justice and reparation for survivors of war including women, children youth and displaced persons.

title.narrative: Inclusive Peace
Number of people better-able to defend rights, redress grievances, resolve disputes peacefully

description.narrative: Counts the active members in local peace and mediation processes in target communities as part of outcome area 3 (inclusive peace). However, the number of empowered people is can also serve as indicator that there has been progress in the outcome areas Security and Justice.

comment.narrative: There were 60 people trained in Wau and Bor about civil rights. During the two days national women leaders' conference, 200 women leaders discussed issues that effects them and vowed to advocate for their rights.

title.narrative: Advocacy Process
Number of times international stakeholders engage in national policy reform processes

description.narrative: Counts number of times that international institutions are present at meetings relevant to national L&A of the programme in the intervention countries.

comment.narrative: The Dutch Embassy in Juba was involved in the development of South Sudan Women Charter.

title.narrative: Number of times constituencies take collective action through and with primary stakeholders (CSOs) to advocate for their demands

description.narrative: Counts the number of times constituencies are actively engaged in L&A initiatives of the programme.

comment.narrative: Women made use of the national leaders conference in Juba to amplify the issues that affect them and advocated for their rights.

title.narrative: Number of youth led primary stakeholders (CSOs) with increased capacity to legitimately represent the most excluded constituencies through advocacy

description.narrative: Counts number of CSOs, CBOs and civil society movements supported by the programme that have made conscious efforts to improve their engagement with their constituencies in setting priorities and discussing strategies for lobby and advocacy .

comment.narrative: Just Future South Sudan through its partner EVE organization broadcasted a radio talk show in Juba where youth discussed issues that affects them.

title.narrative: Number of governmental policies influenced by primary stakeholders (CSOs)
Number of women led primary stakeholders (CSOs) with increased advocacy capacity, cooperation and action to influence and negotiate with duty-bearers and power-holders

description.narrative: Counts number of strengthened CSOs, CBOs and civil society movements involved lobby and advocacy supported by the project.

comment.narrative: This number of CSO were reached during a training of women and youths about civil rights in Wau and Bor.

title.narrative: Number of laws influenced by primary stakeholders (CSOs)
